Simultaneous Wireless Information and Power Transfer for Federated Learning

Jos√© Mairton Barros da Silva Jr.‚ãÜ, Konstantinos Ntougias‚Ä°, Ioannis Krikidis‚Ä°, G√°bor Fodor‚ãÜ‚Ä†, Carlo Fischione‚ãÜ
‚ãÜSchool of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, KTH Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, Sweden
‚Ä°Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Cyprus, Nicosia, Cyprus
‚Ä†Ericsson Research, Kista, Sweden
Email: {‚ãÜ{}^{\star}\{jmbdsj, gaborf, carlofi}@\}@kth.se, {‚Ä°{}^{\ddagger}\{ntougias.konstantinos, krikidis.ioannis}@\}@ucy.ac.cy The simulations were performed on resources provided by the Swedish National Infrastructure for Computing (SNIC) at PDC Centre for High Performance Computing (PDC-HPC). This work has received funding from the European Research Council (ERC) under the European Union‚Äôs Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme (Grant agreement No. 819819).
(March 1, 2024)
Abstract

In the Internet of Things, learning is one of most prominent tasks. In this paper, we consider an Internet of Things scenario where federated learning is used with simultaneous transmission of model data and wireless power. We investigate the trade-off between the number of communication rounds and communication round time while harvesting energy to compensate the energy expenditure. We formulate and solve an optimization problem by considering the number of local iterations on devices, the time to transmit-receive the model updates, and to harvest sufficient energy. Numerical results indicate that maximum ratio transmission and zero-forcing beamforming for the optimization of the local iterations on devices substantially boost the test accuracy of the learning task. Moreover, maximum ratio transmission instead of zero-forcing provides the best test accuracy and communication round time trade-off for various energy harvesting percentages. Thus, it is possible to learn a model quickly with few communication rounds without depleting the battery.

Keywords:
Federated learning, IoT, SWIPT, communication round and time minimization, energy harvesting

I Introduction

Internet of Things (IoT) devices will arguably generate large amount of data, which can be of great use for prediction and inference in several applications of major societal interest¬†[1]. Thus, it is natural to push machine learning solution into the Internet of Things (IoT) devices¬†[2]. However, machine learning is traditionally conceived in centralized settings, where all data is available at one location. When we use machine learning on distributed wireless scenarios, such as the IoT applications, we encounter new challenges for both learning (such as heterogeneity of the data generated by the distributed devices and privacy issues¬†[3]), and communication (such as communication efficiency, interference channel, fading, and battery limitations¬†[4]).

Federated learning (FL) is a recently proposed distributed machine learning technique that attempts to overcome some of these challenges, since it enhances the privacy by sending only model updates instead of raw data, and considers the heterogeneity of devices data and the communication efficiency in the learning convergence¬†[3]. For IoT scenarios, the limited energy storage capacity and high maintenance cost of devices battery is the main challenge¬†[5]. To this end, federated learning (FL) in IoT scenarios must consider the battery of the devices as one of the most important aspects, together with the impact of communication efficiency, interference, and fading.

One promising solution to overcome the energy limitations in IoT is energy harvesting, which allows devices to harvest radio frequency energy when communicating with an edge server, e.g., a base station or access point¬†[6]. Hence, the use of energy harvesting for IoT devices with FL would be a perfect combination. However, how to allow the devices to harvest sufficient energy to train a FL model is largely an open question. This idea is highly novel and, to the best of our knowledge, there is only one similar work in the literature¬†[7]. In¬†[7], the authors consider a wireless power transfer scenario served by power-beacons using FL. Such a work shows that higher density of power beacons improves the learning convergence, and that the mini-batch size and processor clock frequency is inversely proportional to the energy spent in local computation.

Different from the authors in¬†[7], we investigate the trade-off among the number of communication rounds between an edge server and the IoT devices, and the communication round time necessary to train, transmit, and receive the model while harvesting sufficient energy to compensate part of the total energy spent. This trade-off is important to understand in which conditions we can train a FL task without depleting the battery of the devices. We consider a scenario with a multi-antenna edge server using the simultaneous wireless information and power transfer (SWIPT) technology with IoT devices using FL to simultaneously train a learning model, while communicating with an edge server (see Figure¬†1). Moreover, we consider the use of FedProx¬†[8], a recent generalization of FL that allows to optimize the number of local iterations at each device, while guaranteeing convergence to (non-)convex learning tasks. We propose an optimization problem to minimize the number of communication rounds and communication round time while optimizing the number of local iterations, the time to transmit/receive, and to harvest a percentage of the total energy spent at each round and device.

We provide the solution to this problem while considering low transmit power at devices and fixed beamforming techniques, e.g., maximum ratio transmission (MRT) and zero-forcing (ZF), at the edge server. The results indicate that the learning test accuracy using either MRT or ZF with the optimization of the local number of iterations outperform a solution without such optimization. We also show that MRT vastly outperforms ZF in terms of minimum communication round time for all the percentage of the energy harvesting required. Therefore, we show that it is possible to use FL in IoT scenarios without depleting the battery of the devices.

II System Model

We consider a general IoT scenario with an edge server equipped with MùëÄM antennas and KùêæK single-antenna devices (see Figure¬†1). The devices represent sensors gathering data for an FL task and a power splitting SWIPT receiver architecture¬†[6, 9]. In the following, we define the communication, energy, time, and learning models.

Rkd=Bc‚Äãlog2‚Å°(1+Œìkd).superscriptsubscriptùëÖùëòùëësubscriptùêµùëêsubscript21superscriptsubscriptŒìùëòùëëR_{k}^{d}=B_{c}\log_{2}\left(1+\Gamma_{k}^{d}\right). (7)

II-B Energy and Time Models

We define the energy consumption to compute the model at device kùëòk as¬†[10]

Ekc=Œ∫‚ÄãCk‚ÄãAk‚ÄãIk‚Äãfk2,superscriptsubscriptùê∏ùëòùëêùúÖsubscriptùê∂ùëòsubscriptùê¥ùëòsubscriptùêºùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëìùëò2E_{k}^{c}=\kappa C_{k}A_{k}I_{k}f_{k}^{2}, (8)

where Œ∫ùúÖ\kappa is the effective switched capacitance, Cksubscriptùê∂ùëòC_{k} is the number of central processing unit cycles required for computing one sample data at device in Mcycles/bit, Aksubscriptùê¥ùëòA_{k} is the dataset size in bits at device kùëòk, IksubscriptùêºùëòI_{k} is the number of local iterations performed in the training phase by the learning algorithm, and fksubscriptùëìùëòf_{k} is the processor clock frequency at device kùëòk in GHz. Assuming that the uplink transmission occurs during tkusuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëòùë¢t_{k}^{u} seconds and the transmitted power is pksubscriptùëùùëòp_{k}, the energy to transmit the weights in the uplink is Ekt=tku‚Äãpksuperscriptsubscriptùê∏ùëòùë°superscriptsubscriptùë°ùëòùë¢subscriptùëùùëòE_{k}^{t}=t_{k}^{u}p_{k}. Hence, the total energy spent at device kùëòk during one communication round is Ekc+Ektsuperscriptsubscriptùê∏ùëòùëêsuperscriptsubscriptùê∏ùëòùë°E_{k}^{c}+E_{k}^{t}.

We consider a nonlinear energy harvesting model as in¬†[11], in which the harvested power PkhsuperscriptsubscriptùëÉùëò‚ÑéP_{k}^{h} is given by

Pkh=Œ±1‚Äã((1‚àíŒ¥k)‚ÄãPkr)2+Œ±2‚Äã((1‚àíŒ¥k)‚ÄãPkr)+Œ±3,superscriptsubscriptùëÉùëò‚Ñésubscriptùõº1superscript1subscriptùõøùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëÉùëòùëü2subscriptùõº21subscriptùõøùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëÉùëòùëüsubscriptùõº3\displaystyle P_{k}^{h}=\alpha_{1}\left((1-\delta_{k})P_{k}^{r}\right)^{2}+\alpha_{2}\left((1-\delta_{k})P_{k}^{r}\right)+\alpha_{3}, (9)

where Œ±1,Œ±2,Œ±3‚àà‚Ñùsubscriptùõº1subscriptùõº2subscriptùõº3‚Ñù\alpha_{1},\alpha_{2},\alpha_{3}\in\mathbb{R} are parameters of the model. We define the energy harvested at device kùëòk as Ekh=tkd‚ÄãPkhsubscriptsuperscriptùê∏‚Ñéùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëòùëësuperscriptsubscriptùëÉùëò‚ÑéE^{h}_{k}=t_{k}^{d}P_{k}^{h}, where tkdsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëòùëët_{k}^{d} is the transmission time in seconds that the edge server spends to unicast the aggregated weight to device kùëòk. Therefore, we constraint the total energy spent by the total harvested energy at device kùëòk, i.e., Ekt+Ekc‚â§Ekhsuperscriptsubscriptùê∏ùëòùë°superscriptsubscriptùê∏ùëòùëêsubscriptsuperscriptùê∏‚ÑéùëòE_{k}^{t}+E_{k}^{c}\leq E^{h}_{k}.

In the uplink, we assume that device kùëòk has Dksubscriptùê∑ùëòD_{k} bits to transmit, corresponding to the dimension of the weight updates multiplied by the number of bits used to represent each dimension. Thus, each device kùëòk has a constraint tku‚ÄãRku‚â•Dksuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëòùë¢superscriptsubscriptùëÖùëòùë¢subscriptùê∑ùëòt_{k}^{u}R_{k}^{u}\geq D_{k} in the uplink. Similarly, the downlink rate must ensure that the aggregated weight is unicasted to each device. Hence, each device kùëòk has a constraint tkd‚ÄãRkd‚â•Dksuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëòùëësuperscriptsubscriptùëÖùëòùëësubscriptùê∑ùëòt_{k}^{d}R_{k}^{d}\geq D_{k} in the downlink.

In addition, we need to take into account the time necessary for device kùëòk to solve the local problem. Let us denote the time to solve the local training problem device kùëòk as¬†[10]

tkc=Ck‚ÄãAk‚ÄãIk/fk,superscriptsubscriptùë°ùëòùëêsubscriptùê∂ùëòsubscriptùê¥ùëòsubscriptùêºùëòsubscriptùëìùëò\displaystyle t_{k}^{c}=C_{k}A_{k}I_{k}/f_{k}, (10)

where Cksubscriptùê∂ùëòC_{k}, Aksubscriptùê¥ùëòA_{k}, IksubscriptùêºùëòI_{k}, and fksubscriptùëìùëòf_{k} are the same parameters as in Eq.¬†(8). Therefore, we denote the time for one communication round, including the uplink transmission with local computation, and downlink transmission with harvesting time, as tr=maxk‚Å°(tku+tkc)+maxk‚Å°(tkd)superscriptùë°ùëüsubscriptùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëòùë¢superscriptsubscriptùë°ùëòùëêsubscriptùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëòùëët^{r}=\max_{k}\;(t_{k}^{u}+t_{k}^{c})+\max_{k}\;(t_{k}^{d}).

II-C Learning Model

The FL methods¬†[3, 8] are designed to support multiple devices collecting data and a server (edge server in our case) coordinating the global learning objective for the network. The objective of the network is to solve the problem below:

minimizeùê∞ùê∞minimize\displaystyle\underset{\mathbf{w}}{\text{minimize}} f‚Äã(ùê∞)=‚àëk=1KNkN‚ÄãFk‚Äã(ùê∞),ùëìùê∞superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùëÅùëòùëÅsubscriptùêπùëòùê∞\displaystyle f(\mathbf{w})=\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}\frac{N_{k}}{N}F_{k}(\mathbf{w}), (11)

where N=‚àëk=1KNkùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùëÅùëòN=\sum_{k=1}^{K}N_{k} and ùê∞ùê∞\mathbf{w} is the global weight of the network. The devices measure the local empirical risk over different data distributions ùíüksubscriptùíüùëò\mathcal{D}_{k}, i.e. Fk‚Äã(ùê∞)‚âúùîºùêók‚àºùíük‚Äã[fk‚Äã(ùê∞;ùêók)]‚âúsubscriptùêπùëòùê∞subscriptùîºsimilar-tosubscriptùêóùëòsubscriptùíüùëòdelimited-[]subscriptùëìùëòùê∞subscriptùêóùëòF_{k}(\mathbf{w})\triangleq\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{X}_{k}\sim\mathcal{D}_{k}}[f_{k}(\mathbf{w};\mathbf{X}_{k})] in which the expectation is over the NksubscriptùëÅùëòN_{k} samples held by device kùëòk. The function fk‚Äã(ùê∞;ùêók)subscriptùëìùëòùê∞subscriptùêóùëòf_{k}(\mathbf{w};\mathbf{X}_{k}) is the loss function at device kùëòk using its local dataset ùêóksubscriptùêóùëò\mathbf{X}_{k} and the global weight ùê∞ùê∞\mathbf{w}. To reduce the communication of the weights for each device, FL methods consider that each device kùëòk minimizes the loss function Fk‚Äã(ùê∞k)‚âúùîºùêók‚àºùíük‚Äã[fk‚Äã(ùê∞k;ùêók)]‚âúsubscriptùêπùëòsubscriptùê∞ùëòsubscriptùîºsimilar-tosubscriptùêóùëòsubscriptùíüùëòdelimited-[]subscriptùëìùëòsubscriptùê∞ùëòsubscriptùêóùëòF_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{k})\triangleq\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{X}_{k}\sim\mathcal{D}_{k}}[f_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{k};\mathbf{X}_{k})] by using its own data ùêóksubscriptùêóùëò\mathbf{X}_{k} and with its own weights ùê∞ksubscriptùê∞ùëò\mathbf{w}_{k}. Then, the devices send the resulting ùê∞ksubscriptùê∞ùëò\mathbf{w}_{k} to the edge server, which aggregates the weights from each device and sends back the global weight ùê∞=‚àëk=1K(Nk/N)‚Äãùê∞kùê∞superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùëÅùëòùëÅsubscriptùê∞ùëò\mathbf{w}=\sum_{k=1}^{K}(N_{k}/N)\mathbf{w}_{k}. The devices use the global weight as the initial point to minimize Fk‚Äã(ùê∞k)subscriptùêπùëòsubscriptùê∞ùëòF_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{k}), and this process continues until problem¬†(11) converges to the optimal solution.

The FL approach considered is FedProx¬†[8], which guarantees convergence for scenarios with heterogeneous devices and non-convex learning objectives. Due to these advantages, FedProx suits particularly well IoT. To further reduce communication exchange among the edge server and the devices, the local objective function is a surrogate for the global objective function. The surrogate function hk‚Äã(ùê∞k;ùê∞t)subscript‚Ñéùëòsubscriptùê∞ùëòsuperscriptùê∞ùë°h_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{k};\mathbf{w}^{t}) includes a proximal term to the local subproblem with the global update ùê∞tsuperscriptùê∞ùë°\mathbf{w}^{t} at communication round tùë°t. Thus, each device kùëòk solves the following local training problem

minimizeùê∞ksubscriptùê∞ùëòminimize\displaystyle\underset{\mathbf{w}_{k}}{\text{minimize}} hk‚Äã(ùê∞k;ùê∞t)=Fk‚Äã(ùê∞k)+Œº2‚Äã‚Äñùê∞k‚àíùê∞t‚Äñ2,subscript‚Ñéùëòsubscriptùê∞ùëòsuperscriptùê∞ùë°subscriptùêπùëòsubscriptùê∞ùëòùúá2superscriptnormsubscriptùê∞ùëòsuperscriptùê∞ùë°2\displaystyle\;h_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{k};\mathbf{w}^{t})=F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{k})+\frac{\mu}{2}\left\|\mathbf{w}_{k}-\mathbf{w}^{t}\right\|^{2}, (12)

where Œº>0ùúá0\mu>0 is a local configurable parameter. In addition to computing the surrogate function, each device may solve problem¬†(12) inexactly so that a flexible performance depending on the local computation capacity and communication may be included in the solution. Specifically, we introduce the Œ≥ktsuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëòùë°\gamma_{k}^{t}-inexactness for device kùëòk at round tùë°t below.

Definition 1 (Œ≥ktsuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëòùë°\gamma_{k}^{t}-inexact solution).

For a function hk‚Äã(ùê∞k;ùê∞t)=Fk‚Äã(ùê∞k)+(Œº/2)‚Äã‚Äñùê∞k‚àíùê∞t‚Äñ2subscript‚Ñéùëòsubscriptùê∞ùëòsuperscriptùê∞ùë°subscriptùêπùëòsubscriptùê∞ùëòùúá2superscriptnormsubscriptùê∞ùëòsuperscriptùê∞ùë°2h_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{k};\mathbf{w}^{t})=F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{k})+(\mu/2)\left\|\mathbf{w}_{k}-\mathbf{w}^{t}\right\|^{2}, and Œ≥kt‚àà[0,1]superscriptsubscriptùõæùëòùë°01\gamma_{k}^{t}\in[0,1], we define ùê∞k(n)superscriptsubscriptùê∞ùëòùëõ\mathbf{w}_{k}^{(n)} as the Œ≥ktsuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëòùë°\gamma_{k}^{t}-inexact solution of problem minimizeùê∞k‚Äãhk‚Äã(ùê∞k;ùê∞t)subscriptùê∞ùëòminimizesubscript‚Ñéùëòsubscriptùê∞ùëòsuperscriptùê∞ùë°\underset{\mathbf{w}_{k}}{\text{minimize}}\;h_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{k};\mathbf{w}^{t}) at iteration nùëõn if

‚Äñ‚àáhk‚Äã(ùê∞k(n);ùê∞t)‚Äñ‚â§Œ≥kt‚Äã‚Äñ‚àáhk‚Äã(ùê∞t;ùê∞t)‚Äñ,norm‚àásubscript‚Ñéùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùê∞ùëòùëõsuperscriptùê∞ùë°superscriptsubscriptùõæùëòùë°norm‚àásubscript‚Ñéùëòsuperscriptùê∞ùë°superscriptùê∞ùë°\left\|\nabla h_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{k}^{(n)};\mathbf{w}^{t})\right\|\leq\gamma_{k}^{t}\left\|\nabla h_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{t};\mathbf{w}^{t})\right\|,

where ‚àáhk‚Äã(ùê∞k;ùê∞t)=‚àáFk‚Äã(ùê∞k)+Œº‚Äã(ùê∞k‚àíùê∞t).‚àásubscript‚Ñéùëòsubscriptùê∞ùëòsuperscriptùê∞ùë°‚àásubscriptùêπùëòsubscriptùê∞ùëòùúásubscriptùê∞ùëòsuperscriptùê∞ùë°\nabla h_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{k};\mathbf{w}^{t})=\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{k})+\mu(\mathbf{w}_{k}-\mathbf{w}^{t}).

Hence, problem¬†(12) is solved using stochastic gradient descent (SGD) and iterates until a Œ≥ktsuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëòùë°\gamma_{k}^{t}-inexact solution is obtained. The iterations are local at device kùëòk and are termed epochs. Different than the traditional federated averaging method¬†[3], the number of epochs in FedProx is controlled by Œ≥ktsuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëòùë°\gamma_{k}^{t} and may be different for each device.

From¬†[8, Theorem 4 and Corollary 9], the convergence of FedProx is as follows.

Theorem 1 (Convergence: Variable Œ≥ùõæ\gamma‚Äôs).

Assume the functions FksubscriptùêπùëòF_{k} are non-convex, LùêøL-Lipschitz smooth, and there exists L‚àí>0subscriptùêø0L_{-}>0, such that ‚àá2Fk‚™∞‚àíL‚àí‚Äãùêàsucceeds-or-equalssuperscript‚àá2subscriptùêπùëòsubscriptùêøùêà\nabla^{2}F_{k}\succeq-L_{-}\mathbf{I}, with Œº¬Ø‚âúŒº‚àíL‚àí>0‚âú¬Øùúáùúásubscriptùêø0\bar{\mu}\triangleq\mu-L_{-}>0. Consider that BùêµB is a global measure of dissimilarity between the gradients of the devices¬†[8, Definition 3], and suppose that ùê∞tsuperscriptùê∞ùë°\mathbf{w}^{t} is not a stationary solution and the local functions FksubscriptùêπùëòF_{k} are BùêµB-dissimilar. If Œºùúá\mu, KùêæK, and Œ≥ktsuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëòùë°\gamma_{k}^{t} are chosen such that

œÅùúå\displaystyle\rho =((1‚àíŒ≥t‚ÄãB)Œº‚àí(1+Œ≥t)‚Äã(a1+a2‚Äã(1+Œ≥t)))>0,absent1superscriptùõæùë°ùêµùúá1superscriptùõæùë°subscriptùëé1subscriptùëé21superscriptùõæùë°0\displaystyle=\left(\frac{(1-\gamma^{t}B)}{\mu}-(1+\gamma^{t})(a_{1}+a_{2}(1+\gamma^{t}))\right)>0, (13)

then at communication round tùë°t of FedProx, we have the following expected decrease œÅùúå\rho in the global objective

ùîºSt‚Äã[f‚Äã(ùê∞t+1)]‚â§f‚Äã(ùê∞t)‚àíœÅ‚Äã‚Äñ‚àáf‚Äã(ùê∞t)‚Äñ2,subscriptùîºsubscriptùëÜùë°delimited-[]ùëìsuperscriptùê∞ùë°1ùëìsuperscriptùê∞ùë°ùúåsuperscriptnorm‚àáùëìsuperscriptùê∞ùë°2\mathbb{E}_{S_{t}}[f(\mathbf{w}^{t+1})]\leq f(\mathbf{w}^{t})-\rho\left\|\nabla f(\mathbf{w}^{t})\right\|^{2},

where StsubscriptùëÜùë°S_{t} is the set of KùêæK devices selected at iteration tùë°t, Œ≥t=maxk‚ààSt‚Å°Œ≥ktsuperscriptùõæùë°subscriptùëòsubscriptùëÜùë°superscriptsubscriptùõæùëòùë°\gamma^{t}=\max_{k\in S_{t}}\leavevmode\nobreak\ {\gamma_{k}^{t}}, and the constants a1,a2subscriptùëé1subscriptùëé2a_{1},\;a_{2} are

a1=B‚ÄãŒº‚Äã2+L‚ÄãB‚ÄãKŒº‚ÄãŒº¬Ø‚ÄãK,a2=L‚ÄãB22‚ÄãŒº¬Ø2‚ÄãK‚Äã(K+4‚Äã2‚ÄãK+4).‚àéformulae-sequencesubscriptùëé1ùêµùúá2ùêøùêµùêæùúá¬Øùúáùêæsubscriptùëé2ùêøsuperscriptùêµ22superscript¬Øùúá2ùêæùêæ42ùêæ4\displaystyle a_{1}=\frac{B\mu\sqrt{2}+LB\sqrt{K}}{\mu\bar{\mu}\sqrt{K}},\quad a_{2}=\frac{LB^{2}}{2\bar{\mu}^{2}K}(K+4\sqrt{2}K+4).\qed

In the following, we drop the index tùë°t in Œ≥kt,Œ≥tsuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëòùë°superscriptùõæùë°\gamma_{k}^{t},\;\gamma^{t} and refer to them as Œ≥k,Œ≥subscriptùõæùëòùõæ\gamma_{k},\;\gamma to simplify notation, and consider that StsubscriptùëÜùë°S_{t} corresponds to all devices KùêæK. Moreover, the conditions in¬†[8, Remark¬†5] that ensure œÅ>0ùúå0\rho>0, i.e., that sufficient decrease is attainable after each communication round, are the following

Œ≥‚ÄãB<1,B<K.formulae-sequenceùõæùêµ1ùêµùêæ\displaystyle\gamma B<1,\quad B<\sqrt{K}. (14)

Then, the authors in¬†[8, Theorem¬†6] characterize the rate of convergence to the set of approximate stationary solutions ùíÆs={ùê∞|ùîº‚Äã[‚Äñ‚àáf‚Äã(ùê∞)‚Äñ2]‚â§œµ}subscriptùíÆùë†conditional-setùê∞ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptnorm‚àáùëìùê∞2italic-œµ\mathcal{S}_{s}=\{\mathbf{w}\;|\;\mathbb{E}[\left\|\nabla f(\mathbf{w})\right\|^{2}]\leq\epsilon\} of problem¬†(11). Finally, the total number of communication rounds of FedProx is T=O‚Äã(ŒîœÅ‚Äãœµ)ùëáùëÇŒîùúåitalic-œµT=O(\frac{\Delta}{\rho\epsilon}), where Œî=f‚Äã(ùê∞1)‚àíf‚àóŒîùëìsuperscriptùê∞1superscriptùëì\Delta=f(\mathbf{w}^{1})-f^{*}.

In order to define the optimization problem, we first need to derive the number of local iterations (epochs) IksubscriptùêºùëòI_{k}, which depends on the solver used to obtain the optimal ùê∞k‚ãÜsuperscriptsubscriptùê∞ùëò‚ãÜ\mathbf{w}_{k}^{\star} that provides the Œ≥ksubscriptùõæùëò\gamma_{k}-inexact solution. In the following theorem, we establish the expression for IksubscriptùêºùëòI_{k} in terms of Œ≥ksubscriptùõæùëò\gamma_{k}.

Theorem 2.

Consider that the local problem at device kùëòk is solved via gradient descent with step size Œ±<2/(L+Œº)ùõº2ùêøùúá\alpha<2/(L+\mu). Consider that the initial iteration for device kùëòk is given by ùê∞k0=ùê∞tsuperscriptsubscriptùê∞ùëò0superscriptùê∞ùë°\mathbf{w}_{k}^{0}=\mathbf{w}^{t}, and that Œ≤=2/(Œ±‚ÄãŒº¬Ø‚Äã(2‚àíŒ±‚Äã(L+Œº)))ùõΩ2ùõº¬Øùúá2ùõºùêøùúá\beta=2/(\alpha\bar{\mu}\left(2-\alpha(L+\mu)\right)). Then, the number of local iterations IksubscriptùêºùëòI_{k} is lower-bounded by

Based on the theoretical guarantees for the convergence of FedProx, we can now properly formulate the problem in the next section.

III Minimization of Communication Rounds and Round Time

Our objective is to minimize the number of communication rounds between the edge server and the devices, while minimizing the time for each communication round and ensuring that sufficient energy is harvested by the devices. We consider the total number of communication rounds between the edge server and the devices from Section¬†II-C. Given that the term ŒîŒî\Delta cannot be estimated beforehand, we disregard ŒîŒî\Delta and assume that the total number of communication rounds is Ig‚Äã(œÅ,œµ)=1/(œÅ‚Äãœµ)subscriptùêºùëîùúåitalic-œµ1ùúåitalic-œµI_{g}(\rho,\epsilon)\!\!=\!\!1/(\rho\epsilon). Since we aim to minimize the number of communication rounds Ig‚Äã(œÅ,œµ)subscriptùêºùëîùúåitalic-œµI_{g}(\rho,\epsilon), we can maximize œÅùúå\rho, i.e., the expected decrease in the global objective function per communication round, due to its monotonic decreasing relation with Ig‚Äã(œÅ,œµ)subscriptùêºùëîùúåitalic-œµI_{g}(\rho,\epsilon).

We formulate the trade-off between the number of communication rounds and the communication round time using SWIPT to harvest while learning as

where the objective is to minimize the number of communication rounds and the communication round time. Note that problem¬†(18) is jointly convex on all variables because the objective function is concave, while the constraints are convex. Hence, it can be solved by using traditional convex solvers, such as interior-point methods present on CVXPY¬†[12]. The computational complexity is ùí™‚Äã(K4)ùí™superscriptùêæ4\mathcal{O}(K^{4})¬†[13], which is due to the use of interior-point methods to solve problem¬†(18).

IV Numerical Results

We consider a system comprised by a single pico-cell¬†[14]. The total number of antennas at the edge server is M=16ùëÄ16M=16 and the total number of devices is K=10ùêæ10K=10. We consider an image classification learning task using the MNIST dataset and a multi-class logistic regression as loss function. The samples per device NksubscriptùëÅùëòN_{k} are randomly assigned to the devices in a non-IID manner, which ensures that a device will have tens or thousands of samples, and consider 323232 bits encoding, i.e., Ak=32‚ÄãNksubscriptùê¥ùëò32subscriptùëÅùëòA_{k}=32N_{k}. We consider maximum ratio combining (MRC) at the receiver and two transmitter beamforming options namely, MRT and ZF. The test accuracy is the performance indicator used for learning tasks because it represents the percentage of correct predictions. The parameters necessary to obtain the numerical results are listed in Table¬†I.

Figure¬†2 shows the average test accuracy versus the number of communication rounds over 10 Monte Carlo iterations using a baseline FedProx with only one epoch, i.e., without Œ≥ksubscriptùõæùëò\gamma_{k} optimization and using only one SGD iteration. We compare it with the solution of problem¬†(18) by using MRT and ZF beamforming. We assume that Œ∂=1.0ùúÅ1.0\zeta=1.0, which means that in each round the devices must harvest all the total energy spent with the training and transmission. Note that the shaded region for the curves represent the standard deviation at each communication round. Without Œ≥ksubscriptùõæùëò\gamma_{k} optimization, the average test accuracy increases much slower than the MRT and ZF solutions using Œ≥ksubscriptùõæùëò\gamma_{k} optimization. For instance, at 20 communication rounds the average test accuracy of MRT and ZF are approximately 82%percent8282\,\mathrm{\%}, while with one epoch it is only 69%percent6969\,\mathrm{\%}. Moreover, there is almost no difference in the average and standard deviation of the test accuracy for MRT and ZF, which is due to a similar number of local iterations from the solution of problem¬†(18). The energy received by ZF is lower than MRT because ZF nulls the interference from neighbouring users, and thus causes inequality¬†(18c) harder to be attainable. To fulfil inequality¬†(18c), the downlink time is increased and the value of Œ≥ksubscriptùõæùëò\gamma_{k} is decreased, but kept at similar values for both ZF and MRT. Therefore, there are substantial benefits in terms of communication rounds, when optimizing the learning parameters (Œ≥k)subscriptùõæùëò(\gamma_{k}) based on the solution of problem¬†(18).

Figure¬†3 shows the average communication round time, trsuperscriptùë°ùëüt^{r}, across all Monte Carlo iterations versus the percentage of energy harvesting required Œ∂ùúÅ\zeta, when using MRT and ZF beamforming. As Œ∂ùúÅ\zeta increases from 10%percent1010\,\mathrm{\%} to 100%percent100100\,\mathrm{\%}, the communication round time increases much faster for ZF than MRT. It indicates that this difference is due to tkdsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëòùëët_{k}^{d} and that inequality¬†(18c), instead of inequality¬†(16c), is the bottleneck for both MRT and ZF. Since ZF nulls the interference from neighbouring users, the total received and harvested power is lower than the MRT case, as expected from the energy harvesting literature¬†[9]. Moreover, it implies that the necessary time to harvest a Œ∂ùúÅ\zeta-percentage of the total energy used by device kùëòk is much higher with ZF than MRT. Since MRT and ZF have practically the same test accuracy, the MRT beamforming is a better solution to use in a practical scenario because it provides the best trade-off in terms of test accuracy and energy harvesting capabilities within a short communication round time.

V Conclusion

In this paper, we considered the trade-off between the number of communication rounds in a FL model and the necessary communication round time to harvest energy in an IoT scenario. Specifically, our objective was to minimize the total number of communication rounds necessary to learn a model using FL while minimizing the communication round time, which includes the time to compute and transmit the model, and the time to harvest a sufficient amount of the energy spent during training and transmission. Considering fixed transmit beamforming, this resulted in an optimization problem with learning and time parameters that is jointly convex in all the parameters. The numerical results showed that the solution to this problem using either MRT or ZF beamforming achieves a much higher test accuracy than a baseline solution that does not optimize the learning parameters based on communication aspects. We showed that the MRT beamforming solution provides much lower communication round time than ZF beamforming, while achieving practically the same test accuracy. Therefore, we showed that MRT beamforming is able to achieve a much better trade-off in terms of number of communication rounds and communication round time. For future work, we intend to study the impact of using optimized beamforming and energy harvesting parameters together with the learning and time parameters in the aforementioned trade-off.
